title: The rise and fall of the medieval Islamic Empire - Petra Sijpesteijn & Birte Kristiansen

multiple-choice.question: Who united the people of the Arabian Peninsula through the formation of Islam?

options.label: A
options.text: To promote the empire's stability and reduce conflict

options.label: B
options.text: To promote the spread of Islam and unify the empire

options.label: A
options.text: By promoting themselves as more direct descendants of the prophet

options.label: B
options.text: By forming an alliance with the local leaders

options.label: C
options.text: The spread of ideas and knowledge

options.label: C
options.text: The rise of the Abbasid family

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: How did the caliph's reliance on his entourage to stay in power affect the empire?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It led to the empire's decline

options.label: C

title: A brief history of Spanish - Ilan Stavans

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary language spoken by the Romans in the Iberian Peninsula?
Which of the following languages left a strong mark on modern Spanish, including over a thousand words?

According to the text, what is the approximate number of inhabitants of Hispanic America?
What is the name of the language that is a mixture of Spanish and English?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it has a simple grammar system

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has a complex grammar system

options.label: C
options.text: Because of its shared roots in Latin and its ability to adapt to new influences

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has a complex grammar system

options.label: C
options.text: Because there is no easy answer to this question

options.label: D
options.text: Because it has a limited vocabulary

multiple-choice.question: What is the key factor that contributes to the unity of Spanish despite being spoken in many countries?

options.label: C
options.text: Its mixture of syntax, grammar, and vocabulary

options.text: They are trying to escape a predator

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: They are trying to escape a predator

options.label: D

title: The true cost of gold - Lyla Latif

options.label: A

title: The 4 greatest threats to the survival of humanity

multiple-choice.question: What event occurred in January 1995 that brought the world close to a global nuclear war?

options.label: A
options.text: A nuclear missile was launched at Russia.

options.label: B
options.text: A research rocket studying the Northern Lights was mistaken for a nuclear missile.

options.label: C
options.text: A cyber attack was launched on a Russian nuclear facility.

options.label: D
options.text: A natural disaster occurred in Russia.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated rate of natural existential risk per century?
What is a possible consequence of a global nuclear war that could lead to an existential threat?

options.label: B
options.text: A nuclear winter that blocks out the sun for years, causing widespread crop failure and societal collapse

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated anthropogenic existential risk compared to the background rate of natural risk?

options.label: C
options.text: The same as the background rate

multiple-choice.question: What is a concern related to biotechnology that could increase the risk of pandemics?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased costs of genome sequencing and modification

options.label: B
options.text: Increased availability of potentially dangerous information

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B, as they increase the number of people and groups who could potentially create such pathogens

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of people and groups who could potentially create deadly pathogens due to decreased costs of genome sequencing and modification?
What is a possible consequence of unaligned AI that surpasses human abilities?

options.label: C
options.text: An existential risk if it isn't perfectly aligned with human values, which could lead to the collapse of human civilization

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated degree of warming that could cause a calamity of possibly unprecedented proportions?
What are two of the greatest risks that may come from emerging technologies?

options.label: D
options.text: Both B and C, as unaligned AI and biotechnology are two of the greatest risks

title: What causes yeast infections, and how do you get rid of them? - Liesbeth Demuyser

multiple-choice.question: What type of bacteria is usually prevalent in the vagina and produces an acid that lowers the vagina's pH?
What happens when Candida albicans yeasts assume their disease-causing forms?

options.label: A
options.text: They become harmless and are kept in check by the immune system

options.label: B
options.text: They multiply and secrete enzymes that degrade the epithelial cells lining the vagina

options.label: C
options.text: They produce a substance that increases the vagina's pH

options.label: D
options.text: They produce antibiotics to combat other microorganisms

multiple-choice.question: A person is more susceptible to vaginal yeast infections after taking antibiotics. Why is this the case?

options.label: A
options.text: Antibiotics kill only the harmful bacteria, leaving beneficial ones intact

options.label: B
options.text: Antibiotics increase the vagina's pH, making it easier for Candida to multiply

options.label: C
options.text: Antibiotics kill both harmful and beneficial bacteria, allowing Candida to multiply more easily

options.label: D
options.text: Antibiotics have no effect on the vaginal microbiome

multiple-choice.question: What can be done to help prevent vaginal yeast infections?

options.label: A
options.text: Using tight, non-breathable, and wet garments

options.label: C
options.text: Wiping from front to back to avoid introducing more Candida

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of probiotics in treating vaginal yeast infections?

options.label: A
options.text: Probiotics contain harmful yeasts that can cause infections

options.label: B
options.text: Probiotics contain harmless yeasts that can keep Candida in check

options.label: C
options.text: Probiotics have no effect on vaginal yeast infections

options.label: D
options.text: Probiotics are not a recommended treatment for vaginal yeast infections

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to understand the vaginal microbiome?

options.label: A
options.text: There is a lack of research on the subject

options.label: B
options.text: The vaginal microbiome is a complex system that is difficult to study

options.label: C
options.text: There is a stigma surrounding topics related to women's health

multiple-choice.question: What is the typical duration of a vaginal yeast infection?

options.label: A
options.text: It can last for several months

options.label: B
options.text: It usually clears up within two weeks

options.label: C
options.text: It can last for several years

options.label: D
options.text: It can last for a lifetime

multiple-choice.question: What can cause a vaginal yeast infection to recur?
What is the recommended treatment for vaginal yeast infections?
Why is it essential to understand the vaginal microbiome?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop new treatments for vaginal yeast infections

options.label: B
options.text: To improve women's health and reduce stigma surrounding the topic

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the complex interactions between microorganisms in the vagina

title: The world’s slimiest animal - Noah R. Bressman and Douglas Fudge

options.label: B
options.text: To defend themselves from predators and escape from danger

options.label: B
options.text: They are pushed out of the way, allowing the hagfish to escape

options.text: They remain in place and are not affected

options.label: A
options.text: It is extremely hard and brittle

options.label: B
options.text: It is incredibly soft yet tough, with a high volume expansion ratio

multiple-choice.question: How do hagfish create their slime?

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What are some potential applications of hagfish slime?

options.text: Creating a new type of food

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the hagfish's body structure?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It has a large, powerful tail

title: Why can parrots talk? - Grace Smith-Vidaurre and Tim Wright

multiple-choice.question: Where does the sound originate in a parrot's vocalization?

options.label: B
options.text: The tongue and lips, like in humans.

options.label: C
options.text: The syrinx, located at the base of its windpipe.

options.label: D
options.text: The vocal cords, like in songbirds.

multiple-choice.question: Why are parrots able to closely imitate a wide range of sounds, including the human voice?

options.label: A
options.text: This is a result of their need for sophisticated mimicry to communicate with many others in their flock.

options.label: B
options.text: Parrots are not able to closely imitate a wide range of sounds.

options.label: C
options.text: This is a reason why songbirds can closely imitate a wide range of sounds.

options.label: D
options.text: This is a reason why parrots are not able to communicate with other species.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the way parrots and humans produce vocalizations?

options.label: A
options.text: Parrots use their larynx, while humans use their syrinx.

options.label: B
options.text: Parrots have a single vibrating membrane in their syrinx, while humans have two.

options.label: C
options.text: Parrots shape sounds using their tongues and beaks, while humans use their tongue and lips.

options.label: D
options.text: Parrots are able to produce a wider range of sounds than humans.

multiple-choice.question: What is the additional circuit in a parrot's brain that allows them to learn the calls of their own species and other species?

options.label: D
options.text: The polysynaptic vocalization system, also known as the additional circuit.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that parrots have been observed to demonstrate understanding of the words they use?

options.label: A
options.text: They are able to count and pick objects.

options.label: B
options.text: They are able to assign meaning to words in context.

options.label: C
options.text: They are able to repeat their full name and address to strangers.

options.label: D
options.text: They are able to mimic human speech perfectly.

multiple-choice.question: What are potential threats to wild parrot populations?
What is the name of the parrot that became the first non-human animal to pose an existential question?
Why are parrots vulnerable to extinction?

options.label: A
options.text: They are sought by poachers and pet traders, and are losing their habitats to deforestation.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are highly social and live in large colonies.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are highly intelligent and able to learn human speech.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are unable to adapt to changing environments.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that parrots use vocalizations to form social bonds?

options.label: A
options.text: They use contact calls to interact and stay in touch with other parrots.

options.label: B
options.text: They use vocalizations to defend their territory from other parrots.

options.label: C
options.text: They use vocalizations to attract a mate.

options.label: D
options.text: They use vocalizations to communicate with other species.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why parrots are able to bark, scream, curse, and recite factoids?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of their highly developed sense of hearing.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of their highly developed sense of vision.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of their specialized anatomy, including their syrinx and flexible tongue and beak.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of their large brain size.
